IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: PROVIDE A NETWORK OF SENIOR SERVICES INCLUDING A CONTINUING CARE RETIREMENT COMMUNITY IN MECHANICSBURG, COMMUNITY BASED SUPPORT SERVICES AND ENRICHMENT EXPERIENCES FOR THOSE 55+ IN SOUTH CENTRAL PA.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Messiah Village's mission is to be "a ministry that responsibly enhances the lives of older adults with Christ-like love." We believe life is enhanced in three ways: First through an active inward journey of personal growth, secondly through an outward journey of sharing
IRS990.Description: Messiah Village is home to 700 residents in residential living, enhanced living (aka personal care) and nursing care. In addition, Messiah Village served more than 800 adults in the community through home care, adult day, rehabilitation, and Pathways Institute for Lifelong Learning.The 2009-2010 was a year of positive growth and new accomplishments. One special highlight was when Messiah Village was one of forty-four organizations worldwide named as one of the "World Blu Most Democratic Workplaces." This was based solely on employees rating Messiah Village as a participatory workplace. Messiah Village also enjoyed a record-breaking year for fundraising by receiving its largest gift in history. The gift of nearly $900,000 came from the trust of a past resident. This generous gift along with the gifts of many others allowed Messiah Village to reach and exceed its $3.5 million capital campaign goal. The "Connections Campaign" goal was to support benevolent care and seek physical improvements to the Special Care neighborhood in nursing and to the Chapel area. The ground breaking on the new wing of the Special Care neighborhood and new chapel entrance is scheduled for Fall 2010.The Gift Development office used many creative approaches to fundraising this year including: holding special dining nights at local restaurants, hosting two art shows, and organizing a charity croquet tournament. The second annual tournament is scheduled for April 2011 (WicketOnTheGreen.org).Messiah Village has continued to provide benevolent care to older adults who are not able to pay for the full cost of their care. This year, $4.1 million of benevolent care was provided. Another enthusiastic group is the Messiah Village Auxiliary. For many years they have generously supported the Endowment Fund by donating to annual appeal efforts and by donating money from their gift shop and coffee shop sales, quilt auctions, and clothing sales to support benevolent care. Behind the scenes, auxiliary members serve quietly but confidently, knowing that their efforts make a difference to this community. The Connections campaign provided a natural outlet for their charitable spirit. In July 2008, the Auxiliary's Executive Committee approved a $250,000 gift. When complete, the new Northside lobby will be named in the group's honor. As of June 30, 2010, the campaign has accepted $2.4 million in donations.From transporting residents to rehab and hair appointments to planting flowers and hosting at the Fireside Grille, volunteers' generosity of giving time and talent impact nearly every aspect of life at Messiah Village. In spring 2010, 399 volunteers were honored for their 36,286 hours of service to Messiah Village over the last year. Based on the Bureau of Labor and Statistics figures, volunteers provided $734,791 worth of service to the Village. One of the most notable ways in which Messiah Village enhanced the lives of its 350 residents in residential living was through Pathways Institute for Lifelong Learning. The Pathways Institute provides residents with opportunities to engage in mental, cultural and spiritual activities promoting their overall wellness. The program reached a new milestone this year by providing lifelong learning to approximately 200 older adults. Approximately 60% of its members are residents of Messiah Village. Pathways Institute enjoyed multiple media exposures this year.Marketing and Communications worked to continue to create awareness for the many services available to older adults in the region. A key strategy was increasing Messiah Village's online presence through the implementation of a facebook page, blog (MessiahVillageBlog.org), search engine optimization and search engine marketing. Key marketing channels included direct mail, TV, radio, and print advertising.Finally, Messiah Village was recognized again by Harrisburg Magazines as "Simply the Best" long-term care facility in the region. This was the top award for this category in 2010 and is a testament to the quality of care and service that is provided to residents and the greater Harrisburg community.To learn more, visit MessiahVillage.org.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Messiah Village maintains trust fund accounts, primarily for any resident who has exhausted their funds and are benevolent or on Medical Assistance. Each resident has an individual bank account in his or her name and any social security or pension money they receive is deposited into that account. Funds in the individual resident accounts are then swept into a Messiah Village account and the appropriate funds are applied to the cost of the residents' care. Any remaining funds are available for the residents' personal use. The Village also maintains an escrow account which holds funds on deposit from prospective residents for residential living units under construction. If a prospective resident takes occupancy of a unit, the funds are transferred to the Village's operating account and applied to the resident's entrance fee. If the prospective resident changes his or her mind and wants the deposit back, the funds are returned to them.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Investment return on the permanently restricted endowment funds are available for transfer to operations to help offset charity care. The Investment Policy of Messiah Village establishes the method for determining the amount that can be transferred which must be approved by the board prior to the beginning of the year.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Corporation accounts for uncertainty in income taxes by prescribing a recognition threshold of more-likely-than-not to be sustained upon examination by the appropriate taxing authority. Measurement of the tax uncertainty occurs if the recognition threshold has been met. Management determined that there were no tax uncertainties that met the recognition threshold in 2010 and 2009.

Form990ScheduleKPartI.DescriptionOfPurpose: REFUNDING OF TAX EXEMPT BONDS ISSUED IN 2002

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.DescriptionOfTransaction: Mr. Heisey is the Chief Compliance Officer of Capital Blue Cross. Capital Blue Cross provides health care coverage for employees of Messiah Village.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 3
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Dining management was contracted out to CURA Hospitality on 11/1/09 and they took over all food service production and hired all dining staff as of 1/1/10. Rehabilitation was contracted out to Rehab Care beginning in June 2009.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The General Conference of the Brethren in Christ Church confirms all members of the Board of Directors. 75% of the members of the Board of Directors shall be members of the Brethren in Christ Church.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7b
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The General Conference of the Brethren in Christ Church has the right to confirm or deny a board appointment and approves all amendments to the By Laws.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The members of the Finance & Facility Committee of the Board reviewed the Form 990 for the year ending June 30, 2010 at a January 2011 committee meeting with Julius Green of ParenteBeard on hand to review and answer questions.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: EACH BOARD MEMBER, ON AN ANNUAL BASIS, SHALL AFFIRM IN WRITING THAT THEY ARE AWARE OF AND IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE MESSIAH VILLAGE BOARD OF DIRECTORS' CODE OF ETHICS AND CONDUCT WHICH INCLUDES A CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY. MEMBERS MUST DISCLOSE THE FACTS OF ANY CONFLICTING INTEREST AND REFRAIN FROM ANY ACTION THAT MAY HAVE ANY INFLUENCE ON THE TRANSACTION OR POTENTIAL TRANSACTION AFFECTED BY SUCH CONFLICTING INTEREST. THE POLICY IS MONITORED BY MANAGEMENT OF MESSIAH VILLAGE BY VERIFYING ALL FORMS ARE COMPLETED AND SIGNED. ANY VIOLATIONS OF THE POLICY WILL BE HANDLED AS DEEMED NECESSARY. ANY MEMBER WHO INTENTIONALLY VIOLATES THE POLICY WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE BOARD.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board of Directors has established a "Presidential Review Committee" which conducts an annual review of the president. This Committee includes the four officers of the Board (Chair, Vice Chair, Secretary and Treasurer). In addition to establishing this Committee the Board has established a policy to guide the work of the Committee. The purpose of the Committee is to conduct the annual performance evaluation of the president, review past goals and establish future goals, share a summary of the evaluation with the full board, and recommend terms of compensation to the full board. In determining compensation the Board reviews salary data from various sources such as trade association and healthcare alliances. Regarding other officers of the organization, the president conducts an annual performance evaluation. In determining their compensation the president reviews salary data from appropriate trade associations and alliances. The board of directors gives final approval of the compensation of these officers. This process was last undertaken in Calendar 2010.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE ORGANIZATION'S GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ARE AVAILABLE FOR INSPECTION UPON REQUEST.

with others, and finally by journeying together with others. We are committed to being a community that provides opportunities for its members to continue their life's journey. The Principles of Community Life 1. Journey Together - the journey together focuses on relationships, civility, and celebration. This principle is implemented by providing opportunities to journey together through hospitality, respect and participation in the life of the community. 2. Journey Inward - the inward journey focuses on the body, mind and soul of each member of the community. This principle is implemented by providing opportunities for each member of the community to journey inward toward greater purpose, discovery and contentment. 3. Journey Outward - the outward journey focuses on caring for and sharing with others. This principle is implemented by providing opportunities to journey outward through sharing peace, wisdom, and service on campus, in the region and around the world. Intentional and meaningful community life is central to achieving the Village's mission of enhancing life. We believe life can be enhanced when persons have opportunities to pursue their own growth with an inward journey of the body, mind and soul, have opportunities to journey outward and care for and share their hearts and hands with others, and have opportunities to joyously journey together with others and build respectful, participatory relationships.
